<div class="page-intro">
This page presents a simple data visualization created to demonstrate how numerical data can be represented visually to support understanding and analysis.
</div>

<div class="content-card">

## Dataset description

The dataset used in this visualization represents a set of student test scores across five assessments. The values are numerical and allow for direct comparison between different tests.

</div>

<div class="chart-container">

<div class="chart-title">Student Test Scores Across Assessments</div>

```{r}
scores <- c(65, 70, 78, 85, 90)

barplot(
  scores,
  main = "",
  xlab = "Assessment Number",
  ylab = "Score",
  col = c("#667eea", "#764ba2", "#667eea", "#764ba2", "#667eea"),
  border = c("#667eea", "#764ba2", "#667eea", "#764ba2", "#667eea"),
  ylim = c(0, 100),
  las = 1
)
```

</div>

<div class="content-card">

## Key insights

<div class="stats-grid">

<div class="stat-card">
<div class="stat-value">65</div>
<div class="stat-label">Lowest Score</div>
</div>

<div class="stat-card">
<div class="stat-value">90</div>
<div class="stat-label">Highest Score</div>
</div>

<div class="stat-card">
<div class="stat-value">77.6</div>
<div class="stat-label">Average Score</div>
</div>

<div class="stat-card">
<div class="stat-value">+38%</div>
<div class="stat-label">Improvement Rate</div>
</div>

</div>

The data shows a clear upward trend in test scores, indicating consistent improvement across the five assessments. The student improved from 65 in the first assessment to 90 in the final assessment.

</div>
